body: When Rose Brush owned her house, the walls were falling apart, the front steps and interior stairs were crumbling with age, the water heater was worn out, the windows were drafty and the gas company was threatening to shut off service for nonpayment. Although there were was no mortgage, Mrs. Brush found that with income of $900 a month, medical
title: PROBLEMS PERSIST WHEN CITY OWNS HOUSES

body: One of the world's great players thought he had won a major title at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here Saturday, but found he had been overtaken by some unknowns from Iowa. The title - the National Mixed Pair Championship - went to Dr. John Gustafson and his wife, Helen, of Des Moines. Dr. Gustafson is in charge of several
title: Bridge:2 Unknown Players Capture National Mixed Pair Crown

body: IN the 1630's, the Dutch farmers who settled in Brooklyn at what is now the corner of Flatbush and Flatlands Avenues looked around them, saw marshes, a bay and very little high ground and appropriately dubbed the area Flatlands. Not until the post-World War II building boom did Flatlands become a heavily populated residential area, but when it did,
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: FLATLANDS

body: Frank Zuccaro steps out of his patrol car, gun at his side, but without the badge of a New York City police officer. For the people who live along his beat in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn, however, the absence of the silver shield does not matter. Mr. Zuccaro is part of a private security patrol, paid for by homeowners and tenants who feel that
title: PRIVATE SECURITY PATROLS ON RISE IN CITY'S MIDDLE-CLASS AREAS

body: The quarterfinals of the Grand National Teams, raising the curtain for the Summer Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League, began here this afternoon. After 16 deals, New York led the Midwest (Indiana, Kentucky and Ohio) by 11 points; Georgia/North Carolina led Florida by 20; Minnesota led Dallas by 32, and San Francisco led Seattle by 51.
title: Bridge: Play in New Orleans Starts With New York Hopes Up

body: In North America, unlike the rest of the world, bridge clubs have no significance outside their own doors. There are virtually no interclub contests, and if members of a particular club do well in tournament play, nobody pays any attention. Perhaps we should. In the recent Eastern Regional Championships, one club dominated the events restricted to
title: Bridge: Mill Basin Club Should Get More Than Passing Notice

body: LIKE successful big-game hunters, apartment-seekers who land the t rophy of rentable space at an affordable price in New York City are c oming away from their experience with tales to tell. As the spring h unting season wears on, the tales suggest at least two conclusions: - It is extremely difficult for a growing family that needs more space to
title: RENTAL APARTMENTS: HAVES AND HAVE-NOTS

body: Ten years after a school boycott that divided the Canarsie-East Flatbush school district on racial and geographic lines, those divisions are still evident in Tuesday's school board elections. One slate in the district, the 18th, consists mostly of incumbents and is all white. Eight of the candidates are from Canarsie, and one is from East Flatbush.
title: OLD DIVISIONS EVIDENT IN BROOKLYN SCHOOL RACE

body: In an effort to help businesses whose middle-management employees say they have no interest in being transferred to New York City, a leading local business group has listed 61 neighborhoods as good communities for executives and their families. The neighborhoods, recommended by the New York City Chamber of Commerce and Industry for executives
title: EXECUTIVES ARE OFFERED A CITY GUIDE TO HOUSING

body: The American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals resumed here this afternoon with nearly all the favorites in contention in the quarterfinals of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship. In one of the day's key matches, the defending champions, led by Eddie Wold of Houston, met a powerful group with a New York nucleus: Michael Becker, Ron
title: Bridge: Titleholders in Vanderbilt Meet Strong Becker Team

body: Decibels and Motorcycles T he parking lot at the Marine Park municipal golf course on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn was a sea of varooming motorcycles last night. If some City Council members have their way, motorcycles will be banned on residential streets in New York between 9 P.M. and 8 A.M., and that's what brought the two-wheelers out in force
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: SUPPOSE, said Ann Abbruzzese, that a new career was forcing a familyi n Salt Lake City to move to the New York metropolitan area. title: COMPARATIVE PRICING HELPS IN RELOCATION

body: If you have plenty of time for a drive to an airport, a slow but predictable route may be appropriate. But if you are in danger of missing a plane, take the fast highway and pray that you don't run into a traffic jam. Similarly in bridge, if everything seems easy, safety should be a prime consideration. But when in trouble it pays to assume that
title: Bridge: When One Meets Trouble, An Assumption May Work

body: When a vacancy opened at one of the 110 New York City high schools under his jurisdiction, Frank J. Macchiarola made an unusual appointment: He took the job himself. What better way to understand the workings of a school, he explained, when he became acting principal of Jamaica High School in Queens. After nearly five years as New York City Schools
title: THE MACCHIAROLA YEARS: EDUCATIONAL PROGRESS MARKED BY POLITICAL CONFLICTS

body: The Justice Department has decided not to prosecute Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat, on Federal charges in connection with his 1980 campaign for the House, according to senior law-enforcement officials. The department had been reported to be investigating whether Mr. Schumer, a former New York Assemblyman, had unlawfully
title: FEDERAL OFFICIALS WON'T PROSECUTE IN SCHUMER CASE
